message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. External validity refers to the generalizability of study results to other populations or settings. The attending physician's remarks suggest that the study's findings may not be generalizable to the low-income, minority population served by the clinic, even though the study was well-conducted (high internal validity) and reliable. Therefore, the most likely concern underlying the attending physician's remarks is low external validity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The attending physician is concerned about low external validity, which refers to the ability to generalize the findings of a study to a different population or setting. The study was conducted on a sample of upper middle class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands, which may have different demographic and health characteristics than the patient population at the free clinic. Therefore, the attending physician suggests caution in interpreting and applying the study's results to the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The attending physician's concern is likely to be the low external validity of the study, meaning that the results may not be applicable to a different population or setting. The study was conducted in a sample of upper-middle-class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands, and may not be generalizable to uninsured low-income patients in a New York City neighborhood with a large African American and Latino population. This is a common concern in research, as findings may not hold true outside of the specific context in which they were obtained.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The concern underlying the attending physician's remarks is low external validity. The study may not be applicable to the low-income, diverse patient population seen in the clinic's setting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The attending physician’s concern is with the external validity of the study, which refers to the generalizability of the study results to different populations. The study was conducted on a sample of upper middle class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands, and the attending physician is cautious about extrapolating these results to a largely uninsured low-income population of African American and Latino patients in New York City.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. External validity refers to the generalizability of the study results to other populations and contexts. The attending physician's remark suggests that the study may not be applicable to the low-income African American and Latino population being served by the free clinic. This indicates a concern for low external validity. It is important to consider the population and context when interpreting study results, as they may not always be applicable to other populations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The attending physician's concern is most likely about the study's external validity, meaning the ability to generalize the results to a different population. The study was conducted on a sample of upper middle class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands, which may not be representative of the patient population at the free clinic, who are largely uninsured low-income patients from a different ethnic background. Therefore, the attending physician cautions that the study's findings may not be directly applicable to the patient population at the clinic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. External validity refers to the extent to which the results of a study can be generalized to other populations or settings. In this case, the study was conducted in a sample of upper middle class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands, which may not be representative of the patient population at the free clinic, who are largely uninsured and from diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds. Thus, the attending physician's remarks suggest concern about the external validity of the study.

We refer to the definition of terms in medical research. External validity refers to the generalization of findings from a particular study to populations outside of the study. In this case, the attending physician is raising concerns about the external validity of the study, since it was conducted on a very different population (upper middle class Caucasians in the Netherlands) than the patient being treated in the medical student's clinic (low-income African American and Latino patients in New York City). Therefore, the attending physician is cautioning against assuming that the study findings will necessarily apply to this patient population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. External validity refers to the generalizability of study results to populations outside of the study sample. In this case, the attending physician is cautioning against applying the results of the UTI and cognitive impairment study, which was conducted in a sample of upper middle class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands, to the largely uninsured low-income African American and Latino population served by the clinic. This is an issue of external validity.
